reviewText: Despicable Me (Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud, 2010)It's been well over two months since I saw Despicable Me, the all-too-cute first directorial feature from Coffin and Renaud (the latter of whom worked on No Time for Nuts, a short for the Ice Age franchise), and I still haven't reviewed it. I seem to recall having had this same problem with Kung Fu Panda a couple of years ago. What is it about me a kidflicks that doesn't seem to get along, even when I find them eminently enjoyable? No idea, but there it is. Which oddly is exactly what I feel like saying about Despicable Me; to this day, I have no real idea why I enjoyed it as much as I did, and yet here we are.Gru (voice of Steve Carrell) and Vector (voice of Jason Segel) are both arch-criminals. Well, Gru is an arch-criminal, while Vector is more of a screwup arch-criminal wannabe. In any case, they both find themselves competing with one another for loans at the Bank of Evil on a fairly regular basis. When one of those loans goes to Vector (unfairly, Gru thinks), he develops a plot to break into Vector's stronghold and steal a component for a new super-weapon Vector is developing (and will, of course, screw up given the chance). Thus, he adopts three orphans, dresses them up as girl scouts, and sends them off to Vector's to sell robotic cookies that will double as bugs. All well and good, but once the plan goes off, what to do with the kids? Gru finds himself transformed overnight into the role of dad. From there, it's as sappy and predictable a tale of redemption as they come.And yet still, as much as I should hate that sappiness and predictability, it works. And (I don't think this is a spoiler) I don't think it works because Gru is supposed to go through some sort of "I'm no longer a villain!" redemption and doesn't; I think it works because Gru isn't really much of a villain to begin with. He's way too cute and cuddly (as opposed to the odd angularity of Vector, who looks for all the world like Bill Gates to Gru's Bela Lugosi). Yeah, sure, his house is littered with stolen art, but still, even at the beginning, the guy's not a rough-and-tumble criminal. And this is one of those times when I know I should be ripping this movie apart for that, and I just can't because of the cute factor. And the more I realize that the more I realize how manipulative this movie was, and still, I just can't do it. While it's nowhere near in the league of a Kung Fu Panda or even a Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, are the kids going to complain about it? Absolutely not. And it'll work its odd charm on you, as well. *** 1/2

reviewText: As an aficionado of cartoon movies, Despicable Me landed in my sights and I remember eagerly going to see it in theatres. As soon as it was released on DVD I secured my copy from the local store, and a couple years later I can say that I still laugh just as hard today as I did when I first saw it at the 2:30 matinee when it was in theatres.Animation and SoundDespicable Me, an animated comedy presented in both 3D and 2D screenings, is the story of supervillain Gru and his desire to become world-famous for daring capers and heists. Voiced by Steve Carrell, he has a comically shaped body (bowling-ball bald head, carrot-shaped nose, huge torso and skinny legs), with a Russian accent reminiscent of Boris Badinov.The animation itself in the 3D screening is very good; the colors are bright and the small details (worn paint on doors, facial expressions are varied and comical) really do add a nice depth to the film. In terms of the 3D, the movie does deliver but not in any "WOW!!" way. On the upside, the 3D does not feel like a gimmick, either, and the usage of it is both comical and appropriate (the roller coaster ride was awesome and made my stomach do flip flops). In some instances the 3D was a bit blurry, but only during "movement" sequences. For the most part, the 3D was crisp (even though I had to wear the glasses over my own).The lip-synching of the characters was also very impressive, looking natural and well-made. The voices of the characters were great matches, with my only complaint being the voice of the children. With the exception of the youngest girl, the voices seemed a bit "old" for them. It may just be me, but what I am assuming is a 12 year old girl sounds more like an older teenager. Granted, I understand that the eldest, Margo, is supposed to be the "maternal" sibling who is watching out for the other two, but a younger voice would have matched the face a bit better.The music soundtrack for this movie is cute and matches the action. There is nothing especially memorable about it, however, so I do not think that I will be going out of my way to purchase the CD.StoryDespicable Me is very funny, with a clever script and a lot of subtle puns. For instance, Gru applies for a loan through the Bank of Evil; a note on the entrance says "Formerly Lehman Brothers" - obviously a tongue-in-cheek reference and meant more for the adults in the theatre.The plot is simple: Gru plans to steal the moon. To do this, he needs a shrink ray. The movie centers around this concept, trying to explain how Gru will accomplish his goal while balancing his adoption of three oprhan sisters.It is important to remember that this is a kid's movie, so many of the jokes contained therein are geared for a younger crowd. By now, I am sure that many people have seen the Despicable Me commercial that involves the "fart gun"; while I generally think jokes about bodily functions are tasteless, the movie manages to result in many laugh-out-loud moments that revolve around relatively "juvenile" behavior.With all of this being said, the story is a bit predictable (at least, the overall plot), but what makes this movie great is how you get to the end. Gru's "evil" personality results in some great comedic moments. Although Gru tries to be a great villain, his antics usually come across as the petulant actions of a vindictive child. Freezing patrons in the coffeehouse to cut to the front of the line, parallel parking and bumping cars out of the way, driving a huge rocket-powered car that pollutes like mad; these are the extent of Gru's villainry. I found myself laughing quite often at all of this, though, if only because Gru's dedication to evil is so, well, dedicated.Finally, the three orphaned girls who are adopted by Gru and his yellow tic-tac shaped minions are true scene-stealers. The girls are adorable in their resolution, having had to fend for themselves in an orphanage with a self-serving and cruel headmistress. The minions are die-hardedly loyal to Gru, willing to sacrifice themselves for their villainous boss. The girls have a great sense of humor and are rascals, the minions speak in their own language and whack each other whenever possible. There are so many minion and little girl scenes with hysterical commentary and animation that you will definitely feel that the price of the movie admission is worth it.In short, while the plot isn't groundbreaking or even "new", the jokes and wonderful voice talents within the movie will keep you entertained. Even my husband, who normally is not thrilled with "kiddie" movies was chuckling very hard at some moments.The Final VerdictI highly recommend this title for anyone who wants a lighthearted comedy with a heartwarming tale. While you will undoubtedly be able to guess the ending of the movie very early on, sit back and enjoy the jokes and story as it develops. This movie will probably be booed by critics due to its predictability, but I can honestly say that I laughed harder at this movie than I have laughed at any movie for a long while. In fact, the laughs are very much in-line with some of the comic antics from other animated films (such as Shrek), with the script showing the talents of the voice actors and animators. Despicable Me is a fun romp through the warped mind of super villain Gru, resulting in a solid movie that is great for both kids and adults. A very solid A-!

reviewText: I have mixed thoughts about "Despicable Me". I did find it funny and enjoyable more than "Megamind", another villain movie came out that year. I mean, "Megamind" did tell a good story, but it more for super heroes against super villains rather than villains in general like "Despicable Me". I like how Gru changes from a bad guy to good guy with the love of the three girls. Margo is responsible and protective, Agnes is very cute, Edith, eh, I tend to overlook her the most out of the three girls, but her tomboy personality is enjoyable. The minions are enjoyably funny as well, and of course some of the jokes. So why don't I love this film the way everyone else does? Because there are 3 cruel mean-spirited characters that kind of ruin the film for me. One is Ms. Hattie the orphanage owner. She's abusive, cruel, and unfunny. If the filmmakers thought Ms. Hattie's cruelty was supposed to be funny, it totally backfires in my opinion. The second is Mr. Perkins of the villain bank. The way he uses age discrimination against Gru is really unfair, and I thought it was obviously meant just for an excuse to help Vector get the moon! The third is Dr. Nefario, Gru's elderly scientist. I just don't like that guy. I found his hearing problem funny at first, but when he forced Gru to get rid of the girls, I stopped thinking positive of him. He didn't even take responsibility for what he did, and Gru ended up taking the blame, when he said he never should have given up the girls. Why should Gru apologize something for he didn't really do? Dr. Nefario was he one who got rid of them. That is a serious flaw! I was actually hoping Dr. Nefario would get fired or die of old age. Overall, despite "Despicable Me"s problems, I guess I'm okay with it enough to watch with my friends and family. It is funny and all, but I don't think it that great. reviewText: "Despicable Me" is a computer animated film from Universal Pictures / Illumination Entertainment. The delightful comedy revolved around one criminal mastermind named Gru (voice by Steve Carell), who, inspired by the recent heist of a pyramid, vows to become the world's greatest villain by stealing the moon.To do so, however, he needs to borrow from the Bank of Evil. To convince the bank's president Mr. Perkins (Will Arnett) that the project is worth the investment, Gru has to get a "shrink ray" (you can't just carry the moon in your pocket). And to steal the gun from another supervillain wannabe Vector (Jason Segel) ... well, in short, he adopts three orphaned girls Margo (Miranda Cosgrove), Edith (Dana Gaier) and Agnes (Elsie Fisher) for his grand heist plan.The story of "Despicable Me" begins in a digressive manner, making room for Gru the film's "supervillain" to show what kind of a person he really is, and what he can do with his faithful assistant and inventor Dr. Nefario (Russell Brand) and yellow-colored likable "minions." Eventually the story comes down to the bond between the three girls and their surrogate father, but like in a French animation "The Triplets of Belleville," the story is there for the imagination to be explored in the Golden Globe nominated film.The real strength of "Despicable Me" lies in its main character Gru (who looks and acts a bit like Mr. Bean), and his world full of brilliant colors and wry humor. Perhaps the film would have been much better with more distinctive personalities given to the little girls. Still, the film is a very enjoyable ride with a nice blend of humor, sentiment and action.

reviewText: Out of all the films that I have seen this year I would have to say that nothing was more of a letdown than Despicable Me. I am sure you are curious as to why. The acting was great I want to get that off the bat right away. Steve Carrell is an actor that always wows me with every performance live action or voice acting. Giving any actor who is normally looked at as the `good guy' a chance to play a villain is something they always jump at. The supporting cast was also great, Russell Brand was probably the biggest surprise for me just because of the character he voiced.What I hated about this movie was the story. Seeing all the trailers of this movie I really thought this was going to be a film about super villains just going at it trying to headway the crime of the century instead, this film turned out to be nothing but a Disney wanna be, by having Steve Carrells character adopt three orphan girls. Not that I had anything against the characters because the little one was just way too cute. Still, this movie tried way too hard to get at your emotions taking away from the whole super villain element. Also, because of this plot point Jason Siegel gets barely the screen time he deserved in this movie. I am sorry, but if you want to make a Disney movie make sure that Disney does it. I mean yes this film had to go up against Toy Story 3 and there was no way that Despicable Me was even going to match that movie from an emotional standpoint.It's films like this one that make me so mad that animation always has to be stereo typed as being geared towards children or has to be something the whole family can enjoy. Just because it is a cartoon doesn't mean it has to be tame. South Park and the Simpsons got it right making sure their films got PG-13 and above. When will the day come when we will realize that animation can be friendly for all ages so animated movies can be just as enjoyable and exciting as life action?

reviewText: After pretty much working my way through all the Disney/Pixar animated films, "Despicable Me" was my first venture into Universal territory.  The filmmaking styles are most definitely different, although I would argue that Pixar still holds a big edge.For a basic plot summary, "Despicable Me" tells the story of Dr. Gru (voiced by Steve Carell), a supervillian trying to stay on top of the supervillian world.  While dueling with the young, up-and-coming supervillians, Dr. Gru gets involved with a trio of orphan girls who eventually lend him some basic humanity.Clearly, Universal utilizes a completely different formula than Pixar.  Here, the animation is a little goofier and the action almost never ceases.  A bit of emotion is still injected into the film, but nowhere near Pixar levels.  In this case, the never-ending action gets a bit tiresome and the emotion is actually a bit too little, too late.Overall, however, "Despicable Me" will entertain all children with its fast pace, quirky humor, and abundance of sight gags.  For folks any older, though, it just doesn't measure up to the Pixar stable of emotional depth and all-ages humor.
